headline: Sources and acknowledgments

children.data: This report has benefited from many people’s time and help. The author would particularly like to thank:

Nathan Batto, Constance Chang, Emile Chang, Vincent Chao, Chen Chern-chyi, Edward Dunn, Bonnie Glaser, Rupert Hammond-Chambers, Brian Hioe, Chris Horton, Huang Ching-lung, Paul Huang, Jiang Yi-huah, Dean Karalekas, Kuo Lin-wu, Victor Kung, Lai Yuan-yu, Lee Hsi-ming, Lee Ming-che, Annette Lu, Ray Lu, Ivan Kanapathy, Freddy Lim, Anting Liu, Guillermo Martinez, Lev Nachman, T.H. Schee, Puma Shen, Drew Thompson, Happy Tsai, Tsao Chin-jung, Robert Tsao, Nelson Wang, Enoch Wu, Wu Jieh-min, Joseph Wu, Andrew Wylegala, Andrew Yang, Yen Tieh-lin, Diane Ying, and others who prefer to remain unnamed.

bodyText:
This report has benefited from many people’s time and help. The author would particularly like to thank:

Nathan Batto, Constance Chang, Emile Chang, Vincent Chao, Chen Chern-chyi, Edward Dunn, Bonnie Glaser, Rupert Hammond-Chambers, Brian Hioe, Chris Horton, Huang Ching-lung, Paul Huang, Jiang Yi-huah, Dean Karalekas, Kuo Lin-wu, Victor Kung, Lai Yuan-yu, Lee Hsi-ming, Lee Ming-che, Annette Lu, Ray Lu, Ivan Kanapathy, Freddy Lim, Anting Liu, Guillermo Martinez, Lev Nachman, T.H. Schee, Puma Shen, Drew Thompson, Happy Tsai, Tsao Chin-jung, Robert Tsao, Nelson Wang, Enoch Wu, Wu Jieh-min, Joseph Wu, Andrew Wylegala, Andrew Yang, Yen Tieh-lin, Diane Ying, and others who prefer to remain unnamed.

parts.headline: Sources and acknowledgments

parts.description: As video games move from teenage distraction to universal pastime they are following the same path as other mass media, says Tom Wainwright

parts.headline: Ready, player four billion: the rise of video games
parts.description: As video games move from teenage distraction to universal pastime they are following the path of other mass media, says Tom Wainwright

parts.headline: Battles over streaming break out for video games
parts.description: Streaming subscriptions have revolutionised music and television. What will they do to games?

parts.headline: Moviemaking and gamemaking are converging
parts.description: But game developers have a better business model than Hollywood

publication.headline: Frontline Formosa
publication.description: Taiwan’s fate will, ultimately, be decided by the battle-readiness of its people, says Alice Su

parts.headline: Taiwan is a vital island that is under serious threat
parts.description: Taiwan’s fate will, ultimately, be decided by the battle-readiness of its people, says Alice Su

parts.headline: How Taiwan is shaped by its history and identity
parts.description: Understanding Taiwan requires study of its history

parts.headline: It is time to divert Taiwan’s trade and investment from China
parts.description: Taiwan’s economy is strong, but it needs to reduce its dependence on China

parts.headline: Taiwan’s dominance of the chip industry makes it more important
parts.description: No industry matters more to Taiwan than chipmaking

parts.headline: The battle with China is psychological as much as physical
parts.description: The importance of psychology in resisting China

parts.headline: Taiwan needs a new defence strategy to deal with China
parts.description: Taiwan needs to prioritise becoming a porcupine, but ambiguity clouds its strategic decisions

parts.headline: Taiwanese politics faces a crucial election in early 2024
parts.description: The presidential election will do much to decide Taiwan’s future

parts.headline: Taiwan desperately needs support from the world
parts.description: A vibrant small democracy needs protection from a big autocracy

parts.headline: Sources and acknowledgments

parts.description: A superpower conflict would shake the world

parts.description: Higher interest rates are not sufficiently slowing global growth

parts.headline: Strikes at home and war in Ukraine test the French president
parts.description: It is a critical moment for Emmanuel Macron

parts.headline: American universities are pursuing fairness the wrong way
parts.description: Drop legacy admissions—not standardised exams

parts.subheadline: On medical research, fertility in the OECD, soldiers’ mental health, energy firms, the car

author: The Economist
_metadata.articleBody:
This report has benefited from many people’s time and help. The author would particularly like to thank:

Nathan Batto, Constance Chang, Emile Chang, Vincent Chao, Chen Chern-chyi, Edward Dunn, Bonnie Glaser, Rupert Hammond-Chambers, Brian Hioe, Chris Horton, Huang Ching-lung, Paul Huang, Jiang Yi-huah, Dean Karalekas, Kuo Lin-wu, Victor Kung, Lai Yuan-yu, Lee Hsi-ming, Lee Ming-che, Annette Lu, Ray Lu, Ivan Kanapathy, Freddy Lim, Anting Liu, Guillermo Martinez, Lev Nachman, T.H. Schee, Puma Shen, Drew Thompson, Happy Tsai, Tsao Chin-jung, Robert Tsao, Nelson Wang, Enoch Wu, Wu Jieh-min, Joseph Wu, Andrew Wylegala, Andrew Yang, Yen Tieh-lin, Diane Ying, and others who prefer to remain unnamed.
